Title: Breastmilk medicine
Content: Breastmilk medicine refers to the nonnutritional usage of human breast milk. Breastmilk is perceived as an important food that provides essential nutrition. It also provides protection in terms of immunity by direct transfer of antibodies from mothers to infants. The effectiveness of HBM and fresh colostrum as a treatment for inflammatory disorders such as rhinitis skin infection soring nipples and conjunctivitis has been reported. Currently many breastmilk components have shown therapeutic effects on a number of chronic diseases. HBM can be used to treat inflammations. Breastfeeding has an antiinflammatory effect that is conveyed by its chemical components interaction with body cells. The major chemical component that produces the anti inflammatory effect in both colostrum and transitional milk are glycoprotein and lactoferrin. Lactoferrin protects infants against bacterial and fungal infections in combination with other peptides present in HBM Respiratory viral infection in infants. Antiinflammatory effects attributed to its ironbinding properties inhibition of inflammationcausing molecules including interleukin1β IL1β and tumor necrosis factoralpha TNFα preservation of an antioxidant environment. Lactoferrin can interact directly with the F glycoprotein which is a protein on the surface of the virus that is responsible for presenting the virus to body cells and causing infections. HBM can also inhibit the invasion and proliferation of respiratory syncytial virus RSV. Lactoferrin can prevent infection of adenovirus since it can interfere with the primary receptors of the virus. Atopic eczema affects 50 of infants in the first year after birth. Skin thickening may result in chronic or subacute patients due to scratching and fissuring over time. Nonprescription cream containing an antiinflammatory agent 1 hydrocortisone is commonly used. Diaper dermatitis is another prevalent infant dermatological disorder. Common clinical features of diaper dermatitis include inflamed itchy tender skin and soreness in the diaper area. Study results have shown that human breastmilk is highly effective in healing diaper rash. The immunological components in HBM help strengthen the babys immune system. These include antimicrobial proteins that can inhibit or kill a wide range of pathogens. This antimicrobial effect could be achieved by indirectly creating an unfavorable environment for the growth of pathogens by modifying commensal flora pH or level of bacterial substrates. Topical application of expressed breastmilk has long been a nonpharmacological intervention to reduce nipple pain. According to the research outcome of many studies topical application of HBM can help reduce the perception of nipple pain in a treatment course of 4 to 4 weeks. HBM is more effective in lowering pain perception than Lanolin. Lanolin produces lower pain levels in mothers with nipple pain than HBM. Lanolin shows a better therapeutic effect for healing rates nipple trauma and nipple pain. Although lanolin may be more efficacious than H BM to cure nipple problems HBM is not proven to be ineffective. The topical application of breastmilk as a treatment for an infectious disease called conjunctivitis has been present since ancient times in different nations such as ancient Egypt Rome Greece etc. HBM was also recommended by the Greek physician Galen as a remedy for conjunctvitis.
